newsitem.title: USA: Dow Jones, Microsoft in development pact.
newsitem.headline: Dow Jones, Microsoft in development pact.

text.p: Dow Jones & Co. Inc. and Microsoft Corp. said Tuesday they planned to jointly develop new information and transactions systems for financial institutions.

The companies did not announce any specific plans or disclose any financial details, but they said the alliance will combine Microsoft's operating systems and applications and its leadership in Internet technologies with Dow Jones' content, delivery capabilities and transactional services.

In January, Dow Jones announced plans to invest up to $650 million over the next 36 to 48 months in its Dow Jones Markets unit to expand its content and services and to upgrade its delivery systems and presentation technologies based on open Internet standards.
With Microsoft technology and products, Dow Jones said it expects to be able to begin rolling out new capabilities later this year.

"Dow Jones understands the potential of the communications revolution to offer new products and services to its customers, and is leading the way as the financial services industry reinvents itself," said Bill Gates, Microsoft chairman and chief executive.

Kenneth Burenga, president of Dow Jones and chief executive of Dow Jones Markets, said, "By working closely with Microsoft, we will be staying ahead of the technology curve. With Microsoft's assistance, Dow Jones intends to put our financial services customers at the centre of their trading markets."
